description: From Middle English commencen, comencen (also as contracted comsen, cumsen), from Anglo-Norman comencer, from Vulgar Latin *cominitiāre, formed from Latin com- + initiō (whence English initiate).

verbs.description: commence (third-person singular simple present commences, present participle commencing, simple past and past participle commenced)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To begin to be, or to act as.
examples: […]  he furnish’d me with a Gun, Cartouch-box, and Powder-horn, &c. and thus accouter’d I commenc’d Soldier.

entries.meaning: (UK, intransitive, dated) To take a degree at a university.
examples: […]  was admitted a minor fellow of his college 4 Oct. 1591, a major fellow 11 March 1591-2, and commenced M.A. in 1592.
